item.title: Python basics
item.description:
Build a foundation in Python.

1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks

Learn

Quiz

What is the difference between lists and tuples?

Lists

  • Lists are mutable - they can be changed
  • Slower than tuples
  • Syntax: a_list = [1, 2.0, 'Hello world']

Tuples

  • Tuples are immutable - they can’t be changed
  • Tuples are faster than lists
  • Syntax: a_tuple = (1, 2.0, 'Hello world')

Is Python case-sensitive?

Yes

item.title: Visualization
item.description:
Learn how to visualize data with Plotly.

1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks

Learn

Quiz

When is a heatmap useful?

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

Write Plotly code to render a bar chart 

import plotly.express as px
data_canada = px.data.gapminder().query("country == 'Canada'")
fig = px.bar(data_canada, x='year', y='pop')
fig.show()

item.title: Statistics
item.description:
Introduction to statistics for data science.

1-2 hours per week, for 8 weeks

Learn

The general form of the normal probability density function is:

$$ f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi} } e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2} $$

The parameter $\mu$ is the mean or expectation of the distribution. $\sigma$ is its standard deviation. The variance of the distribution is $\sigma^{2}$.

Quiz

What is the parameter $\mu$?

The parameter $\mu$ is the mean or expectation of the distribution.

item.title: 关于我的眼镜
item.description:
这是4年前买的眼镜，Warby Parker牌的。

就在前几日， 我心血来潮，嫌弃这眼镜有点镜片有点磨损的厉害，便想着该换了。

验光完的第二天，在我擦拭镜片的时候，发现左边的金属边框有个若隐若现的裂缝。当时不以为然。

过了两日，又去 Warby Parker 的门店光顾。选了新的镜架。然需要等待2到3周。记得4年前，最多也就等了一周吧。是公司的业务量上去了还是疫情的影响呢？

又过了两日，刚睡醒的我又擦拭起了我的眼镜。“铛”，左边的镜片掉落，那边框也断了。正是那个几天前我不在意的小裂缝。难道是它知道有新的它会替代它，所以自行“罢工”了？

新眼镜还需等待两周， 旧的眼镜又罢了工，只能用上我那带度数的墨镜。戴上墨镜，世界一下子就暗了下来。想着明天还得教课，脑子里面画面感十足的播放着上课的情形， 不免有些紧张却又期待。

回到我这戴了4年的眼镜。想想，这也是一段不短的陪伴了。想想，我这四年看的东西，都是穿过它的两片镜片。想想，这四年又有多少失去联系的朋友。想想，还有多少我不以为然的“小裂缝”。

再见了，我的眼镜。

item.title: A note on Venakides1989 paper about continuum limit of theta functions
item.description:
Claim 1: For any $f\in \mathcal{H}$, there is $m_\epsilon\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$, such that \begin{align*} \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)\rightarrow \Phi(f),\quad \text{as $\epsilon\rightarrow 0$}. \end{align*}

Proof: Since $f\in \mathcal{H}\subset L^2[0,1]$, it can be uniformly approximated by a rational valued simple function. Without loss of generality, we assume $f$ is a rational valued simple function, and define it as \begin{align} f(\eta)=p_\sigma+\frac{\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma},\quad \eta \in (\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}),\quad \sigma=1,…,M, \end{align} where $(0,1]=\bigsqcup_{\sigma=1}^M(\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}]$, and $p_\sigma,0\leq \alpha_\sigma<d_\sigma$ are all integers. For such $f$, and fix $\epsilon$, we construct the vector in $\mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$ as follows: \begin{align} m_j=\begin{cases} p_\sigma+1 \text{ at the first $\alpha$ indices of $J_\sigma$},\\ p_\sigma \text{ at the next $d_\sigma-\alpha$ indices of $J_\sigma$}, \end{cases} \end{align} where the index set $J_\sigma=\{j|\eta_j\in (\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1})\}.$ Now we construct a function $f_\epsilon$ in the following way: \begin{align} f_\epsilon(\eta)=m_j,\quad \eta\in [\frac{1}{2}(\eta_{j+1}+\eta_{j}),\frac{1}{2}(\eta_j+\eta_{j-1})). \end{align} Then, one can show that \begin{align} f_\epsilon\rightarrow f,\quad \text{weakly}\quad as \quad \epsilon\downarrow 0. \end{align} That is to say \begin{align} \int_{0}^1f_\epsilon(\eta) d\mu(\eta)\rightarrow\int_0^1 f(\eta)d\mu(\eta). \end{align} In fact, by linearity of Lebesgue integral, we have \begin{align} \int_0^1f_\epsilon(\eta)d\mu(\eta)&=\sum_{\sigma=1}^M\int_{\xi_\sigma}^{\xi_{\sigma+1}}f_\epsilon(\eta)d\mu(\eta)\\ &\sim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\sum_{\sigma=1}^M \left((1+p_\sigma)\frac{\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma}+p_\sigma\frac{d_\sigma-\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma}\right)\mu([\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}])\\ &=\sum_{\sigma=1}^M \left(\frac{\alpha_\sigma}{d_\sigma}+p_\sigma\right)\mu([\xi_\sigma,\xi_{\sigma+1}])\\ &=\int_0^1 f(\eta)d\mu(\eta). \end{align} Then one can easily show that \begin{align} \Phi_\epsilon(m)\rightarrow\Phi(f_\epsilon). \end{align}

Now, if we set $f^*$ to be the (unique) minimizer of $\min_{f\in\mathcal{H}}\Phi(f)$, then by claim 1, we can find a sequence of $\Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)$, such that

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon \downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)=\Phi(f^*). \end{align}

Meanwhile, for any $\epsilon$, if $\Phi_\epsilon(m)$ assumes minimum at $m^*_\epsilon$, then we have

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m^*_\epsilon)\leq \Phi(f^*), \end{align}

in other words, we have

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\min_{m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}}\Phi_\epsilon(m)\right)\leq \min_{f\in \mathcal{H}}\Phi(f). \label{leq} \end{align}

Claim 2: For any $m_\epsilon\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$, there is $f_\epsilon\in \mathcal{H}$, such that \begin{align} \liminf_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\Phi_{\epsilon}(m_\epsilon)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\right)\geq 0. \end{align}

*Proof: * Fix $\epsilon$ and $m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}$, define a piece-wise integer-valued function $f_\epsilon$ as follows: \begin{align} f_\epsilon(\eta)=m_j,\quad \eta\in [\frac{1}{2}(\eta_{j+1}+\eta_{j}),\frac{1}{2}(\eta_j+\eta_{j-1})). \end{align} Then as $\epsilon\rightarrow 0$, we see that $\Phi_{\epsilon}(m)$ converges to \begin{align} \Phi(f_\epsilon)-\int_{0}^1\gamma(\eta)\phi(\eta){\frac{1}{4}-(f_\epsilon(\eta)-[f_\epsilon(\eta)]-\frac{1}{2})^2}d\eta, \end{align} that is to say \begin{align} \Phi_\epsilon(m)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\rightarrow \int_{0}^1\gamma(\eta)\phi(\eta){\frac{1}{4}-(f_\epsilon(\eta)-[f_\epsilon(\eta)]-\frac{1}{2})^2}d\eta,\quad as\quad \epsilon\downarrow 0. (*) \end{align} Apparently, the right hand side (*) is non-negative, which implies that \begin{align} \liminf_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\Phi_\epsilon(m)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\right)\geq 0. \end{align}

To apply the claim 2, we split the sequence ${\Phi(f_\epsilon)}_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}$ into two subsequences:

$$ (1). \quad \{\Phi(f_\epsilon)|\Phi(f_\epsilon)\geq \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)\}_{\epsilon\downarrow 0} $$

$$ (2). \quad {\Phi(f_\epsilon)|\Phi(f_\epsilon)< \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)}_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}. $$

In the case (1), since $ \liminf_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\Phi_{\epsilon}(m_\epsilon)-\Phi(f_\epsilon)\right)\geq 0$, we have

\begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi(f_\epsilon)=\lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m^*_\epsilon), \end{align}

where we have chosen $m^*_\epsilon$ to be the minimizer for each fixed $\epsilon$. Thus, we have

\begin{align} \min_{f\in\mathcal{H}}\Phi(f)\leq \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi(f_\epsilon)\leq \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\Phi_\epsilon(m^*_\epsilon) \end{align}

In the second case, we have $\Phi(f_\epsilon)< \Phi_\epsilon(m_\epsilon)$, if we choose $m_\epsilon$ to be the minimizer, then it immediately implies \begin{align} \min_{f\in\mathcal{H}}\Phi(f)\leq \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\min_{m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}}\Phi_\epsilon(m)\right).\label{geq-2} \end{align}

Combine all above together, we have proved that \begin{align} \lim_{\epsilon\downarrow 0}\left(\min_{m\in \mathbb{Z}^{N(\epsilon)}}\Phi_\epsilon(m)\right)= \min_{f\in \mathcal{H}}\Phi(f). \end{align}

The variational equation

Recall the functional \begin{align} \Phi(f)=2<a\phi,f>+<\gamma \phi,f^2-(f-[f]-\frac{1}{2})^2+\frac{1}{4}>+<T(\phi f),\phi f>, \end{align} where $a,\gamma,\phi\in C[0,1]$, $\phi $ and $\gamma$ are strictly positive, $Tf(\eta)=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^1\tau(\eta,\mu)f(\mu)d\mu$ is a symmetric positive definite bounded operator in $L^2(0,1)$.

  1. Prove it is strictly convex, thus it attains its minimum value at a unique element in $\mathcal{H}={f\text{ measurable on } [0,1] :|\Phi(f)|<\infty}$
  2. Find the variational equations, which are \begin{align} a+T(\phi f)+\gamma[f]+\frac{1}{2}\gamma&=0,\quad if\quad f>[f]\\ a+T(\phi f)+\gamma[f]+\frac{1}{2}\gamma&\in [0,\gamma], \quad if\quad f=[f], \end{align} where $f=[f]+r,0\leq r<1.$
  3. Now consider the Green potential:\begin{align} T(\phi f)(\eta)=\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{0}^1\log{\left|\frac{\eta-\bar\mu}{\eta-\mu}\right|}f(\mu)\phi(\mu)d\mu, \end{align} How to construct a explicit solution to the variational equation?

As for the answer, we are still working on that.

item.title: 关于梦境
item.description:
曾做了好多奇怪的梦。现在却也忘记的差不多了。

有几个梦是重复的。

又一次， 我梦到我开车行驶在沿海公路（或许是跨海公路）， 路的左边是山， 右边是悬崖，悬崖下面就是大海。 大概就是加州一号公路的样子。那个梦好像也发生在那次旅行后不久。

那不是一个好梦。一开始，风和日丽；下一秒竟然骤雨狂风。是一个末日之类的梦。梦境其实很真实。我开着开着，右边的公路开始坠落，天空忽然也变得晦暗， 海浪也是异常的汹涌。 路边的漂亮房子被这海浪一口一口的吞噬。

我不记得副驾有没有人， 也不记得我当时的心情。人做梦的时候会有心情吗？

我就一直开，一直开，仿佛只要我不承认世界末日， 那滔天的巨浪就是小小的浪花而已。

不知道何时，我醒来了。醒来的时候并不觉得惊喜，似乎还满喜悦。

大概是我觉得梦境本就不真实，相比于显示，梦里面的世纪末日无非是种电影院的体验。

有人会觉得梦在预示这什么， 我不知道这个梦到底想要告诉我什么。现在，我甚至觉得这是我编造的梦。

梦和谎言，哪一个会更加真实一点，我们不得而知。

于我而言，梦里没有谎言，没有道德，没有伤害，没有感情。

item.title: Integral equation of the first kind
item.description:
Background

Integral equations play important roles in mathematical physics. In this short note, we are going to discuss a class of integral equation of the first kind. My motivation to study those equations is from soliton gas, where the nonlinear dispersion relation is as follows: $$\int_\Gamma g(z,w)u(w)|dw|+\sigma(z)u(z)=\phi(z),\quad z\in \Gamma$$

where $\Gamma$ is some simple smooth rectifiable curve in $\mathbb{C}^+$ and kernel $g(z,w)=\log\left|\frac{z-\bar w}{z-w}\right|$ is so-called Green kernel (i.e. it is the Green function to the Direchlet problem on the upper half plane.). The case when $\sigma\equiv 0$ is referred to as soliton condensate. As one can immediately see, the equation becomes Fredholm equation of the first kind. It is well-known that integral equation of the first kind is (in general) ill-posed in the sense of Hadamard. Here we are going to consider a slightly different equation: $$\int_{\Gamma}\log|w-z|^{-1} u(w)|dw|=f(z),\quad z\in \Gamma.$$

And we will consider the uniqueness of the equation using classical potential theory. Then we will use a method introduced by Yan&Sloan to solve the equation explicitly.

Potential theory and uniqueness

Let’s first introduce some definitions from classical complex analysis. All the definitions and theorems can be found on Hille’s book.

Definition 1. Let $\mu$ be a probability measure supported in $\Gamma$ (i.e. $\mu(\Gamma)=1$.), the logarithmic potential is $$U^{\mu}(z)=-\int_\Gamma \log\left|z-w\right|d\mu(w),\quad z\in \mathbb{C}.$$

Definition 2. The energy is defined as $$I(\mu)=\int U^{\mu}(z) d\mu(z).$$

Definition 3. The capacity of a compact set $\Gamma$ is defined as $$C_\Gamma=e^{-V_\Gamma}=\exp{(-\inf_{\mu\in M(\Gamma)}I(\mu))},$$ where $V_\Gamma$ is so-called Robin constant.

Definition 4. A charge is a signed measure, which always has the decomposition as $\sigma=\sigma_+-\sigma_-$, where $\sigma_\pm$ are called positive and negative part of the charge. And we denote the space of charge with finite energy as $S(\Gamma)$.

Now let’s list some classical results from Hille’s book.

Lemma 1. Let $\Gamma$ be a compact set with positive capacity, ans $S\subset\Gamma$ has zero capacity. If $\mu\in M(\Gamma)$ and $I(\mu)<\infty$, then $\mu(S)=0$. The same statement if also true for charges (exercise).

Lemma 2. If $C_\Gamma>0$, then there is a unique measure $\mu_e$ such that $I(\mu_e)=\inf_{\mu\in M(\Gamma)}I(\mu)$.

Lemma 3. Let $\Gamma$ be a compact set with positive capacity. Then $U^{\mu_e}(z)\leq V_\Gamma,\quad z\in \mathbb{C}$ and $U^{\mu_e}(z)= V_\Gamma,\quad z\in \Gamma, q.e.$.

Lemma 4. Let $\sigma\in S(\Gamma)$ and $\sigma(\Gamma)=0$. Then $I(\sigma)\geq 0$ and “$=$” iff $\sigma\equiv 0$.

Based on the lemmas we mentioned above, we can easily prove the following theorem.

Theorem 1. Let $\Gamma$ be compact and $\sigma\in S(\Gamma)$ generates constant potential, i.e. $U^{\sigma}(z)=c,z\in \Gamma$, q.e., then $c=\sigma(\Gamma)V_\Gamma$ and $\sigma=\sigma(\Gamma)\mu_e$.

proof. Write \red{$\sigma=\sigma(\Gamma)\mu_e+\sigma_0$}, then $\sigma_0(\Gamma)=0$ and it belongs to $S(\Gamma)$. Thus for each $z\in \Gamma$, we have $$ U^{\sigma_0}(z)=c-\sigma(\Gamma)V_\Gamma, q.e. $$ Then $$ I(\sigma_0)=(c-\sigma(\Gamma)V_\Gamma)\sigma_0(\Gamma)=0. $$ By lemma 4, $\sigma_0\equiv 0$, and the result follows.

Corollary 1. Suppose $\Gamma$ is compact with $C_\Gamma\neq 1$, if $\sigma\in S(\Gamma)$ is such that $U^\sigma(z)=0,z\in \Gamma, q.e.$, then $\sigma\equiv 0$.

Theorem 2.(Uniqueness) Let $\Gamma$ be a piecewise smooth with finite length and $C_\Gamma\neq 1$, assume $g\in L_p(\Gamma)$ with $p>1$ such that \begin{align*} -\int_\Gamma \log|z-w| g(w)|dw|=0,\quad \forall z\in \Gamma, \end{align*} then $g\equiv 0$.

Solution Methods

We are now in the position to construct the solution. The method is due to Yan-Sloan, see reference[3] for more details. The existence will follow as we find a way to construct it. First, let’s recall some notations for Sobolev spaces.

Let $C^\infty_e$ denote the set of even smooth $2\pi$ periodic functions on $\mathbb{R}$. For each $v\in C_e^\infty$, we have \begin{align*} v(s)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\left(\sum_{m\in\mathbb Z_+}\hat v(m)\cos{ms}+\frac{1}{2}\hat v(0)\right), \end{align*} with $ \hat v(m)=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\int_0^\pi v(s)\cos{(ms)}ds, m=0,1,2,\cdots. $ Define the weighted norm in terms of the Fourier series: \begin{align*} |v|^2_t=2\sum_{m\in \mathbb{Z}_+} m^{2t}|\hat v(m)|^2+|\hat v(0)|^2. \end{align*} Definition [Weighted Sobolev space] $$H_e^t(2\pi) = \text{Closure}\{C_e^\infty(2\pi),|\cdot|_t\}.$$

To connect it to our equation, we recall the following well-know indenty: For any $v\in H^0(2\pi)$, we have \begin{align*} -\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi\log\left|2e^{-1/2}\sin\frac{t-\tau}{2}\right|v(\tau)d\tau=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\left(\sum_{|m|>0}\frac{\hat v(m)}{|m|}e^{imt}+\hat v(0)\right):=Av(t). \end{align*}

The operator $A$ defined above has very good properties. In fact, $A$ is an unitary operator from $H^t$ to $H^{t+1}$ for any $t\in \mathbb R$. Moreover, When $t>0$, we have \begin{align} A^{-1}v=-D^2Av+Jv=-DADv+Jv=-HDv+Jv,\quad v\in H^{t+1},\nonumber \end{align} where $Jv=(1/\sqrt{2\pi})\hat v(0)$, $Dv(t)=v'(t)$, and $H$ is the Hilbert transform: \begin{align*} Hv(t)=-\frac{1}{2\pi} p.v.\int_{-\pi} ^\pi \cot{\frac{t-\tau}{2}}v(\tau)d\tau. \end{align*}

Existence for simple smooth closed curves

Consider a closed smooth simple curve $\Gamma$. Then there is a function $v$ from $C^{\infty}(2\pi)$ such that $v: [-\pi, \pi]\rightarrow \Gamma$ and $v'\neq 0$. Then the integral equation of the first kind can be transferred to $$Kw(t):=-\frac{1}{\pi}\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\log|v(t)-v(\tau)|w(\tau)d\tau=f(t),\quad t\in [-\pi, \pi],$$ where $w(\tau)=u(v(\tau))|v'(\tau)|$ and $f(t)=\phi(v(t))$

Theorem If $\Gamma$ is smooth closed and simple with $C_\Gamma\neq 1$, then $K:H^t\rightarrow H^{t+1}$ is bijective.

Proof. Write $K=A+B$, where the kernel of $B$ is $-\frac{1}{\pi}\log\left|e^{1/2}\frac{v(t)-v(\tau)}{2\sin(\frac{t-\tau}{2})}\right|$, which is smooth! This implies $B$ is compact. Then note $K=A(I+A^{-1}B)$, and that $A$ is unitary, apply standard Fredholm theory, the result follows.

An Examples from El-Tovbis: simple open arc case

Let $\Gamma=[-iq,iq],q>0$, the integral equation is \begin{align*} -\frac{1}{\pi}\int_\Gamma\log|z-w|u(w)|dw|=\Im z,z\in \Gamma. \end{align*} Apply Yan-Sloan’s method, set $v(x)=-iqx,a(t)=v(cos(t)),t\in [0,\pi].$ The equation becomes \begin{align*} -\frac{1}{\pi}\int_0^\pi\log|\cos(t)-\cos(\tau)|g(\tau)d\tau=f(t), \end{align*} with $g(t)=u(-iq\cos(t))\sin(t)$ and $f(t)=-\cos(t)+\frac{\log q}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\hat g(0)$.

The using one of the two identities, we have \begin{align*} \begin{cases} \hat q(0)\log (q/2)=0\ \sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}}\hat g(1)=-1\ \hat g(m)=0,m>1. \end{cases} \end{align*} This implies $g(t)=-\cos t+c$, where $c=\begin{cases} 0,q\neq 2\\ \in i\mathbb R , q=2.\end{cases}$. Since when $q=2$, $C_\Gamma=1$! Then we have \begin{align*} u(z)= (-iz+ic)/\sqrt{q^2+z^2}. \end{align*} In El-Tovbis, they assume $u$ is anti-Schwarz sysmmetrix, then $c$ must be 0.

References

  1. G.A. El and A. Tovbis, Spectral theory of soliton and breather gases for the focusing nonlinear Schr"odinger equation, Phys. Rev. E 101, 052207 (2020).

  2. A. Kuijlaars and A. Tovbis, On minimal energy solutions to certain classes of integral equations related to soliton gases for integrable systems, Nonlinearity, 34, n. 10, 7227 (2021)

  3. Yan, Y., and Sloan, I. H. On integral equations of the first kind with logarithmic kernels. The Journal of Integral Equations and Applications, 549-579.(1988)

  4. Einar Hille, Analytic function theory, Vol II, AMS Chelsea Publishing, 2nd edition, (2005)

item.title: The Continuum Limit of Theta Functions
An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Create your slides in Markdown - click the Slides button to check out the example.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code, math, and images.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Wowchemy

Wowchemy | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One **Two** Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: An example conference paper
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Create your slides in Markdown - click the Slides button to check out the example.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code, math, and images.
